Name: Tax, Property, Childrens Defense Fund
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to the establishment of a children's defense and development fund; setting aside funds from the city property tax for a children's defense and development fund; establishing a children's service planning commission; and preparation of a children's service plan.
Text:
Be it enacted by the Council as follows:

     	Section 1.  The New York city charter shall be amended by adding a new chapter 75 to read as follows:
Chapter 75
Children's Defense and Development Fund
     	 �3022. The children's defense and development fund.  a. The mayor shall direct the comptroller to establish and maintain a fund, separate and apart from the general fund, for a period of ten fiscal years following the effective date of the local law that added this section to expand children's services, which shall be called the "children's defense and development fund" (hereinafter "the fund"). Monies shall be set aside for the fund from the revenue of the tax levy on real property in the city of New York, in an amount equal to three-fourths of one cent of each one dollar ($1.00) of real property taxes collected for the first fiscal year; revenues in an amount equal to one and one half cents for each one dollar ($1.00) of real property taxes collected in the second fiscal year; revenues in an amount equal to three and one-eighth cents for each one dollar ($1.00) of real property taxes collected in the third fiscal year, and revenues in an amount equal to six and one quarter cents for each one dollar ($1.00) of real property taxes collected for each of the remaining fiscal year of the fund.  The fund shall be used exclusively to supplement, and not to supplant, funds for services already provided for children and educational services to children less than twenty-one years of age. The fund shall not be used for services that only benefit children incidentally, or as members of a larger population of children and adults, nor shall it be used for functions and services provided by the judiciary, the department of correction, police department or other law enforcement agencies, such as youth detention and probation services.
     	b. During the term of the fund the spending for children's services shall not be reduced below the higher of the fiscal year 1993 or fiscal year 1994 levels of spending for such services.
     	c. During each fiscal year in which the fund shall be in effect, a minimum of forty percent (40%) of the money deposited into the fund shall be expended to plan and implement a phased-in reduction of class size in public schools until the following teacher-student ratios are achieved in every subject class: primary grades, one classroom teacher to every fifteen to twenty students; secondary grades, one classroom teacher to every twenty to twenty-four students.  No funds transferred to the board of education pursuant to this subdivision may be used for purposes other than class size reduction. Any funds not used for that purpose, or any funds the board of education refuses to accept, shall be used by the fund for other purposes in accordance with the annual plan.
     	d. During the first four years of the fund, a minimum of fifteen percent (15%) of the money deposited into the fund shall be used for day care; a minimum of fifteen percent (15%) of the money deposited into the fund shall be used for health and social services, including child protective services; a minimum of fifteen percent (15%) of the money deposited into the fund shall be used for youth employment and training and youth development and diversion programs and opportunities for entrepreneur training programs, including but not limited to recreation, performing arts, and visual arts (to the extent possible these services shall be provided by not-for-profit community-based service providers); a minimum of five percent (5%) of the money deposited into the fund shall be used to increase and improve support services to public school students, including but not limited guidance counselors, paraprofessionals and family paraprofessionals; and a minimum of four percent (4%) of the money deposited into the fund shall be used for community service programs for college students domiciled in New York city.  Community service programs shall be defined as programs that provide experimental internships in the areas of education, public health, environmental rededication, public works and mentoring of children and adolescents.
     	e. The mayor shall prepare and present to the speaker of the city council a children's services plan pursuant to section 103 of this charter; such children's services plan shall propose goals and objectives for the fund for the fiscal year immediately following the effective date of the local law that added this section.
     	     	�3023. Duties and powers of the children's service planning commission. a. There shall be a children's service planning commission that shall annually prepare, submit and propose to the mayor, city council, each borough president and the board of education, a children's service plan in time to be reviewed, evaluated, adopted and revised by the mayor, and included in the preliminary expense budget, executive expense budget and financial plan submitted pursuant to chapter six of this charter.  The children's services plan for the expenditure of the fund shall include the commission's plan relating to the expansion and improvement of services provided to youth, including adequate and appropriate resources for a planned reduction in class size in public schools pursuant to this chapter.  Thereafter, the commission shall annually propose and publish a five-year plan for the expenditure of the funds in the Fund.
     	b. Before submitting the annual children's service plan, the commission shall review, evaluate, monitor, and assess policies, practices, programs, facilities, staff and equipment and the delivery of services to children, in city agencies which provide services to children, including but not limited to the board of education, city and community colleges, the health and hospital corporation, the department of health, department of employment, department of juvenile justice, department of social services and the department of youth services.
     	c. The commission shall also review, evaluate, monitor, and assess policies, practices, programs, facilities, staff and equipment and the delivery of services to children, in all city agencies which provide services to children, including but not limited to the board of education, city and community colleges and the health and hospital corporation, to ensure that such agencies and the board of education are complying with the annual children's service plan adopted by the mayor and the city council.
     	d. The commission shall consist of eleven members who shall be compensated for their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties hereunder.  The mayor shall appoint one member of the commission, subject to the advice and consent of the city council, who shall serve as its chair. Each borough president shall appoint one member who shall serve at the pleasure of the borough president.  Each borough delegation within the city council shall nominate one member whose appointment shall be subject to the advice and consent of the city council.  Members shall be chosen for their integrity, related to children's issues.
     	e. Members shall be appointed for four-year terms expiring on the fifteenth day of February after each mayoral election, except that the members first appointed shall serve for terms expiring on the fifteenth day of February after the next mayoral election following the effective date of the local law that added this section.
     	f. The commission may, within the appropriations available therefor, appoint an executive director and such deputies, assistants, and other employees as may be needed for the performance of the duties prescribed herein, and may request and shall receive from any agency such assistance as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter.  The commission shall appropriate no more than $400,000 annually for its administration and to publish, distribute, monitor and evaluate the annual children's service plan.
     	g. The commission may meet as necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter provided, however, that the commission meet at least once every eight weeks.
     	h. The commission shall publish an annual report to the mayor, the city council and the board of education on the activities of the commission to comply with the purposes of this chapter.
     	i. The commission shall conduct such studies or investigations and hold such hearings as may be necessary to assist the commission in the preparation of the children's services budget plan or to determine whether city agencies which provide services to children, including but not limited to the board of education, city and community colleges, and the health and hospitals corporation, are in compliance with the requirements of this chapter.  The commission may request and shall receive from such city agencies which provide services to children, such information, other than information required by law to be kept confidential or which is privileged as attorney-client communications, attorney work products or material prepared for litigation, and such assistance as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter.
     	�2. Section one hundred and three of the New York city charter  is
hereby amended by adding a new paragraph (h) to read as follows: 	
	(h) 	the children's services plan pursuant to chapter seventy-five of the charter.
     	�3. This local law shall take effect immediately.
